learning_outcomes.description: Describe how genomics can lead to gene-editing applications and the development of new vaccines, to benefit livestock industries and animal health.

Describe the impact of reproductive technologies and genomics on livestock breeding, and consequently food production, including the opportunities to reduce the environmental impact of these industries.

Apply the knowledge gained in the theoretical component of the course to current problems in the livestock sector, including opportunities to reduce the environmental impact, increase productivity, and enhance animal health and welfare.
Discuss the importance and the pitfalls associated with using (or not) livestock biotechnologies; including their social-economic impact related to food security in diverse societies.
Contribute to an informed debate on scientific issues, in a group setting.
Communicate in writing and verbally at an appropriate level for an early career scientist.
Source and critically review relevant information from the literature.
Describe how animal ethics and regulations apply to livestock biotechnologies.

assessments.due_date:
1/08/2025 - 10/10/2025

You need to complete at least 8 of the 10 Padlet contributions to pass the course. This is a course requirement, as the tutorials are your practical classes for this course. Padlet entries must be completed before we start the tutorials on Friday.
assessments.task_description:
Each week students will submit a Padlet contribution articulating their question for the paper being discussed as part of the group discussions (weeks 1-10). Submit one or two sentences that comprise your question and some context. In total, the Padlet contributions are 10% of your final mark (1% each week).

Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT)

This assessment task evaluates students' abilities, skills and knowledge without the aid of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT). Students are advised that the use of AI or MT technologies to develop responses is strictly prohibited and may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Place your contributions in each weekly section of the Padlet using the link provided to you on the course Blackboard page. Use your student number and name to identify your Padlet contribution. Submit before the start of the class discussion.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.due_date:
Part 1 29/08/2025 2:00 pm

Part 2 10/10/2025 2:00 pm

Finish the quiz at 16:00 (4 pm). This is an online quiz to be done during class. Bring your own device and complete the quiz in class.
assessments.task_description:
The online quiz is formed by multiple-choice questions related to the course lectures. The quiz will occur in 2 parts: after the first and the second block of lectures. Each part is 13% of the final mark. In due weeks, we will use the second part of the tutorial to allow time for you to do the online quiz. Bring your device to class to complete the quiz in class.

Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Learning (MT)

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.late_submission: Exams submitted after the end of the submission time will incur a late penalty.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.due_date:
23/10/2025 8:00 am

Students will present their literature critique verbally in person, during class time. We have a special 4-hour session in weeks 11 and 12 for this activity. In week 11, we will have a tutorial session about how to present the verbal critique. In week 12, students will deliver their verbal presentations for marking.
assessments.task_description:
Students will present their literature critique verbally in person, during class time. Presentations should be 3 minutes long, and PowerPoint slides are allowed.

Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT)

This assessment task evaluates students' abilities, skills and knowledge without the aid of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT). Students are advised that the use of AI or MT technologies to develop responses is strictly prohibited and may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Submit your slides one day before the pitch presentation, by 10 am on 22 October 2025. The PowerPoint document must have your name and student number as the file name. The course coordinator needs these slides before the due date to organise the presentations, there is no time to be switching between computers or various files on the presentation day.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
The literature critique in this course is a hand-written essay completed under exam conditions during the end-of-semester exam period, approximately one to two pages. You will critique one biotechnology topic discussed in class, using the scientific literature provided to you. During the course, you will practise critical reading and learn how to structure and write a scientific critique. You are expected to apply this learning in your final essay. Detailed instructions, marking criteria, and examples will be provided in class and on Blackboard.

Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT)

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Week 11(28 Jul - 19 Oct)
learning_activities.topic:
Weekly Tutorials

Two-hour group discussions, and Padlet activity, for enhancing your knowledge about the topic introduced in each Lecture. It is important to view the lecture content and to read the prescribed paper so that you can make the most of these sessions. This tutorial includes an opportunity for Q&A. Padlet assignment is linked to this activity (see course profile for assessment details).


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06, L07, L08
learning_activities.topic_description: Weekly Tutorials Two-hour group discussions, and Padlet activity, for enhancing your knowledge about the topic introduced in each Lecture. It is important to view the lecture content and to read the prescribed paper so that you can make the most of these sessions. This tutorial includes an opportunity for Q&A. Padlet assignment is linked to this activity (see course profile for assessment details).

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Week 10(28 Jul - 12 Oct)
learning_activities.topic:
Lecture series

In this course, you will have a series of lectures, including the following topics:

  1. Modern animal breeding requires reproductive and genomic technologies
  2. Semen analyses and preservation
  3. Genome sequencing technologies and genotyping DNA
  4. Genomic Selection
  5. Reproductive Biotechnologies: AI, FTAI, IVF, Cloning, and gene editing - all applied to livestock breeding
  6. Animal Ethics
  7. Reverse Vaccinology

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L07, L08
learning_activities.topic_description: Lecture series In this course, you will have a series of lectures, including the following topics: Modern animal breeding requires reproductive and genomic technologies Semen analyses and preservation Genome sequencing technologies and genotyping DNA Genomic Selection Reproductive Biotechnologies: AI, FTAI, IVF, Cloning, and gene editing - all applied to livestock breeding Animal Ethics Reverse Vaccinology
